desc.p: Indicates the value date applicable to the currency purchased. The liquidation of the Foreign Exchange contract will take place on the earliest date between the VALUE.DATE.BUY and the VALUE.DATE.SELL but taking into account the respective value dates.

The Foreign Exchange application has two separate fields in which to record a value date for the currency bought and the currency sold. In most foreign exchange deals the two dates will be identical as both currencies will be dealt under the same value. However, in foreign exchange deals where one Middle East currency is involved it will often happen that, due to differences in country holidays, the two currencies could be dealt with a one or two days difference in their value date. In this case a specific input will then be done in the two fields VALUE.DATE.BUY and VALUE.DATE.SELL. In order to enter a Forex deal for which the value dates are not the same as each other, one or both currencies of the deal must be defined in the field SPLIT.VALUE.CCY on the FX.PARAMETERS table.

If neither currency of the deal is listed on this table, any input to the field VALUE.DATE.BUY will automatically be assigned to the field VALUE.DATE.SELL and vice versa. If no input is done in the field VALUE.DATE.SELL, it will then default automatically to the value of the field VALUE.DATE.BUY.

This date will be compared with the deal date to identify if the deal is a spot or forward contract. The classification of the deal as 'Spot' or 'Forward' will depend on the number of days defined in the field SPOT.INTERNAL on the FX.PARAMETERS table.
The calculation of default spot date is also controlled by the FX.PARAMETERS fields FX.LCL.REGION and SPOT.BASE.CCY which allow the use of alternative or additional holiday tables.
Where an OPTION.DATE is entered, it is this option date and not the VALUE.DATE.BUY entered in this field which is used to identify if the contract is to be classified as Spot or Forward.
To ease user input, the following abbreviations will also be allowed:
T = Todays date
TO = Tomorrow
S = Spot date as defined in the field Spot Market on the FX.PARAMETERS table.

ON = Refers to a two leg SWAP contract where the value date on the first leg is equal to today's date and the value date on the second leg is equal to the next working day. The abbreviation 'ON' stands for 'OverNight'.

TN = Refers to a two leg SWAP contract where the value date on the first leg is equal to the next working day and the value date on the second leg is equal to the following working day. The abbreviation 'TN' stands for 'Tom Next' i.e. 'Tomorrow - Next'.

SN = Refers to a two leg SWAP contract where the value date on the first leg is equal to the spot date (see above) and the value date on the second leg is equal to the following working day. The abbreviation 'SN' stands for 'Spot Next'.
NNA = Where NN is the number of days or months and A is either 'D' for calendar days, 'W' for working days or 'M' for months. Examples:
IOD = 10 calendar days forward (from Spot) 10W = 10 working days forward (from Spot) 6M = 6 months forward (from spot)
The date may be entered in the standard date format or as one of the abbreviations explained in the details. (Input is mandatory for forward deals; otherwise input is optional).
The date must be in an acceptable format (see general formats).
A date less than today is not allowed except for Spot deals. Where the date entered is more than one day back value or more than one year forward value, an override is required.

This field is used when the counterparty of the deal instructs us to pay funds to another party who does not have an account with us.

When a contract matures, funds must be moved to actually settle the contract. This involves paying the counterparty or his nominated beneficiary for the currency sold and receiving funds for the currency purchased. The counterparty will advise us of where the money which we have sold is to be paid and we will advise them where we require the currency purchased to be remitted. The delivery of funds will normally be as one payment but may be in several instalments.

If the beneficiary is known to us (i.e. there is a customer record), the beneficiary details should be entered in the BENEFICIARY.NO field. If unknown to us, details should be entered in this multi-value field. Note that, where the beneficiary requests the funds into an account he has with us, this should be specified in the OUR.ACCOUNT.PAY field.
It is important to note that when the Beneficiary is specified, the Counterparty Correspondent field will be used to indicate the bank of the beneficiary.
The counterparty may ask us to pay the amount sold in a number of ways:
To an account with us

We may pay the funds directly into an account provided it is in the same currency as that being sold. To make payment directly to a counterparty's internal account the relevant account number should be entered in the OUR.ACCOUNT.PAY field and no other input will be necessary in this field.
To an account at another bank overseas

To pay money to another bank overseas we would have to advise our agent, in the country concerned, to pay to the counterparty's bank. In this case, the Nostro account number of our agent should be entered in the OUR.ACCOUNT.PAY field. If the counterparty's bank is known to us (i.e. there is a customer record), then the bank's number should be entered in CPARTY.CORR.NO if these details have not yet been defined on the Agency file. If the bank is not known to us, (i.e. there is no customer record) the bank's name and address should be entered in the multi-valued field CPARTY.CORR.ADD. When known, the counterparty's account number at his bank should be entered in the field CPARTY.BANK.ACC.
To an account at another bank locally

Where payment is to be effected locally, settlement can be through a number of different methods. The most common are Banker's Payments, CHIPS, or CHAPS. In all cases, the number of our internal clearing account, or our clearing agent should be entered in OUR.ACCOUNT.PAY. Details of the counterparty's bank account should be completed as detailed above.
To a beneficiary of the counterparty

The counterparty may nominate a third party beneficiary of the funds. If the beneficiary is to be paid by crediting an account with us, the account number should be entered in OUR.ACCOUNT.PAY. If the beneficiary does not have an account with us, the internal clearing number or Nostro account of our agent should be entered in OUR.ACCOUNT.PAY.

Where we are paying to another bank but the beneficiary is known to us (i.e. there is a customer record), the customer number of the beneficiary will be entered in the field BENEFICIARY.NO. Where no relationship exists, the payment details will be entered in the multi-valued field BENFCY.ADD.
Payment via an intermediary bank

Occasionally the counterparty may ask for payment to be made through an intermediary bank. This occurs where the counterparty or beneficiary's correspondent is not in the country of the currency involved. As an example, let us say that the Bank 'ABC' in Hong Kong uses Bank 'XYZ' in Hong Kong as their dollar agent. When a dollar payment is to be made we would pay American Bank in New York (the Intermediary) for Bank 'XYZ in HK (the Cparty correspondent), account Bank 'ABC' (the Cparty or Beneficiary). The Intermediary can be entered as a number in the INTERMED.BK.NO field if a customer relationship exists (i.e. there is a customer number) or as narrative in the Intermed Add field.

Identifies the position type applicable to the foreign exchange transaction. This facility is not used at present.

Typically any bank will maintain a 'TRADING' position which will reflect the net position of all dealing and back office activity. On the other side, the management of the bank could also decide, from time to time, to take a position outside the normal trading activity and which consequently will not be included in the day to day trading activity and position but instead in a separate position which will generally be called 'Management' position. This position will then be under the exclusive control of the management itself and will only consist of a very small number of foreign exchange deals (1 or 2). For the dealing room trader this management position will be transparent as it is normally outside his area of responsibility.

Any foreign exchange deal where the position type 'Management' has been indicated, must be classified as internal and will update at the same time and in the opposite sense the Management position and the Trading position. The foreign exchange dealer will then make a second deal in the market to cover his own trading position. Only the Management position will then exist at this stage. When management decides to liquidate or undo this position, the reverse operation will take place.
Before a type can be entered it must first be created on the FX Pos Type table.

Example: Let us suppose that the management believes that the U.S. dollar will go down against the Deutsche Mark in the near future and that, for this reason, decides to sell one month forward 10 million dollars against Deutsche Mark. The following deals will then be created:

1) Internal deal between trader and management. The trader will buy dollars from management and sell Deutsche Mark to management which consequently will be short in dollars and long in Deutsche Marks. To keep the cost of the trading position intact, the exchange rate applicable to this transaction will normally be the rate agreed in the next deal (external deal).

2) The trader, to keep intact his trading position will make an opposite contract in the market for the same amount, rate and maturity date. The following position will then exist across the books of the bank:

Trading Position ---------------- DEM USD - = SELL to management + = BUY from management + = BUY from the market - = SELL in the market _______________________ _______________________ SQUARE POSITION SQUARE POSITION
Management Position ------------------- DEM USD + = BUY from trader - = SELL to trader ______________________ _____________________ Long in DEM Short in USD
During the revaluation process, separate accounting entries will be generated for the Management position to strictly isolate any exchange Profit or Loss which will result from this position.

Contains the limit reference number for the counterparty.
The reference can be entered by the operator or left blank. If left blank the system will provide the default Limit reference number for FOREX deals.
The Limit system covers two main types of exposure as far as the FOREX application is concerned. These are:
1. Overall Foreign Exchange Limit

Each deal is monitored against the overall foreign exchange limit of the respective counterparty to ensure that the bank is not overly exposed to this specific counterparty. This overall Foreign Exchange Limit can furthermore be sub-divided to allow definition of Time bands. This would allow to define different limits for Spot and Forward dealing.
2. Clean Risk or Delivery Risk Limit

The clean risk limit is the maximum allowable value of foreign exchange transactions from the same counterparty to mature on any single day. For example, the bank may be prepared to have an Overall Foreign Exchange limit of GBP 20 Million with a given counterparty, but may want to limit the delivery risk on any one day to GBP 5 Million.

The system does allow for netting of the Overall Foreign Exchange Limit for opposing deals with the same counterparty when the two opposing deals involve the same two currencies and mature on the same day. For example, if the bank buys USD 100,000 from a counterparty for GBP 70,000 to be settled on 31st December and then sells USD 50,000 to the same counterparty for GBP 35,000 to be settled on the same day (December 31st), the net effect would be an overall foreign exchange exposure of USD 50,000.
Note that within this approach the Clean Risk is never netted.

Identifies the base currency of the deal. It will be used to verify the exchange rate and to indicate the spread (if quoted) on customer deals.

When the Base Currency is not specified and the transaction involves local Currency, the System will default to the local Currency provided that the Quotation code of the other Currency is NULL. If this is not the case (the Quotation code of the other Currency is not equal to null) then the other Currency will become the default.

When the base Currency is not specified and the transaction involves two currencies where none is the Local Currency the system will prefer one with a RANK.BASE.CURRENCY field. If both currencies have values for this field then that with the lower value will be chosen as the base. If both are blank it will default to the Currency which yields a cross-rate greater than unity (One).

Example 1: A UK User is processing a Foreign Exchange transaction involving Pounds Sterling and American Dollars. The base Currency which will be defaulted to in this case will be Pounds sterling because the Quotation code of the U.S. Dollar will be equal to null in the Currency table, i.e. in United Kingdom it is the Pound Sterling (local Currency) which is the Currency against which all foreign currencies are quoted.

Example 2: A UK User is processing a Foreign Exchange transaction involving Swiss Francs and Deutsche Marks. The base Currency which will be defaulted in this case will be the Swiss Franc because it is the Currency which yields a cross-rate greater than unity. If a rate of 0.80 has been input, the User will be forced to indicate that the Deutsche Mark is the base Currency otherwise the Exchange Rate routine would refuse the rate input for incompatibility with the rates contained in the Currency table.
The proper identification of the base Currency will allow the Exchange Rate routine to control the Exchange Rates input by the User against the Exchange Rate values contained in the Currency table.

Contains the foreign currency amount of the profit or loss accrued to-date on the 'Swap' or 'Forward' contract where the revaluation type 'IN' or 'IH' has been specified. This field will be increased daily by the amount specified in the daily accrual foreign currency table.

Contains the account number of the counterparty or nominated beneficiary at their correspondent bank.
The field will be used to provide the correspondent with the necessary details to credit the counterparty's or beneficiary's account.

When a contract matures, funds must be moved to actually settle the contract. This involves paying the counterparty or his nominated beneficiary for the currency sold and receiving funds for the currency purchased. The counterparty will advise us of where the money which we have sold is to be paid and we will advise them where we require the currency purchased to be remitted. The delivery of funds will normally be as one payment but may be in several installments.
If the bank is known to us (i.e. a customer record exists), details should be entered in the CPARTY.CORR.NO No field. If not, the should be entered in this multi-valued field.
The counterparty may ask us to pay the amount sold in a number of ways:

To an account with us ===================== We may pay the funds directly into an account provided it is in the same currency as that being sold. To make payment directly to a counterparty's internal account the relevant account number should be entered in the OUR.ACCOUNT.PAY field and no other input will be necessary in this field.

To an account at another bank overseas ====================================== To pay money to another bank overseas we would have to advise our agent, in the country concerned, to pay to the counterparty's bank. In this case, the Nostro account number of our agent should be entered in the OUR.ACCOUNT.PAY field. If the counterparty's bank is known to us (i.e. there is a customer record), then the bank's number should be entered in CPARTY.CORR.NO if these have not yet been defined on the Agency file. If the bank is not known to us (i.e. there is no customer record), the bank's name and address should be entered in the multi-valued field CPY.CORR.ADD. When known, the counterparty's account number at his bank should be entered in the field CPARTY.BANK.ACC.

To an account at another bank locally ===================================== Where payment is to be effected locally, settlement can be through a number of different methods. The most common are Banker's Payments, CHIPS, or CHAPS. In all cases, the number of our internal clearing account, or our clearing agent should be entered in OUR.ACCOUNT.PAY. Details of the counterparty's bank account should be completed as detailed above.

To a beneficiary of the counterparty ==================================== The counterparty may nominate a third party beneficiary of the funds. If the beneficiary is to be paid by crediting an account with us, the account number should be entered in OUR.ACCOUNT.PAY. If the beneficiary does not have an account with us, the internal clearing number or Nostro account of our agent should be entered in OUR.ACCOUNT.PAY.

Where we are paying to another bank but the beneficiary is known to us (i.e. there is a customer record), the customer number of the beneficiary will be entered in the field BENEFICIARY.NO. Where no relationship exists, the payment details will be entered in the multi-valued field BENFCY.ADD.

Payment via an intermediary bank ================================ Occasionally the counterparty may ask for payment to be made through an intermediary bank. This occurs where the counterparty or beneficiary's correspondent is not in the country of the currency involved. As an example, let us say that the Bank 'ABC' in Hong Kong uses Bank 'XYZ in Hong Kong as their dollar agent. When a dollar payment is to be made we would pay American Bank in New York (the Intermediary) for Bank XYZ in HK (the counterparty correspondent), account Bank ABC (the counterparty or Beneficiary). The Intermediary can be entered as a number in the INTERMED.BK.NO field if a customer relationship exists (i.e. there is a customer number) or as narrative in the INTERMED.ADD field.

The UTI.USI.API attached in OC.PARAMETER and invoked during FX deal capture (FW and SW) determines who is the party responsible for UTI generation and does the following. • If a value is present during deal capture the API is not invoked, on the assumption that the UTI is generated and supplied by the other Counterparty. • If no value is present during the deal capture, the API is invoked to determine the party responsible for generating the UTI. If the Other counterparty is responsible, still an UTI is generated with a suffix as TEMP to show that the UTI from the other counterparty is awaited and in the meantime, the reporting is done with a Temporary ID. If T24 Bank is responsible for UTI generation, then the same is generated without TEMP. • Where a reporting has been made with UTI having TEMP as suffix and subsequently the Counterparty supplies the UTI, the following procedure has to be followed to ensure reporting with actual UTI. • The field Action Type needs to be changed to ‘E’ and record to be authorized. Later, the UTI field should be modified with the actual UTI received. Set the Action Type field to ‘N’ and authorize the record. In this way, the previous reporting gets cancelled and the new reporting goes with correct UTI.

Action Type ‘E’ is also used to undo the reporting of a particular transaction done which should not have been done reported at all in the first instance.
M denotes that the ACTION.TYPE is MODIFIED.A modification to any Primary Economic Terms (PET) like a partial settlement made in case of FX trades.

Z denotes Compression update. This means the trade being reported is generated out of a compression activity.
